moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6: The Philidor Defense, considered inferior to the Queen's Knight and Petroff Defense because it blocks in the dark-squared bishop. Oddly there is no recorded game where Philidor played this.
moves.3. d4: Challenging Black's center, and trying to open up the game.
moves.3... f6: Defending the center, a poorer move than Nd7 or exd4. This unfortunately takes Black's Knight's best square and weakens the Black Kingside.
moves.4. Bc4: Developing the Bishop which turns out to be the key piece in the combination.
moves.4... Ne7: I think Nd7 was best here.
moves.5. Nc3: Dxe5 immediately was best but I didn't see that then, I just developed normaly.
moves.5... a6: ?? Trying to keep my knight and bishop off this square, but missing the threat of dxe5.
moves.6. dxe5: Starting the combination, which with good play on each side wins only a pawn.
moves.6... fxe5: b5 or Nbc6 here were much much better, this was his first real blunder.
moves.7. Nxe5: Threatening mate, a hard threat to deal with.
moves.7... dxe5: ?? Big blunder which loses the queen. I think d5 here was the only move.

gameName: Games of The Ashaman - Death by Bishop
